headline: Octopus filmed 'walking' its way back to sea on UK beach after battering storms
author: Rhodri Harrison
sentences: "We get so many tourists here who aren't in tune with the natural world, that had this happened in summer, it probably would have ended up in someone's bucket to no end of prodding and poking.
Josh told WalesOnline : "It's not something you see everyday... rock pool and coastal wildlife is fascinating to look at, but it's important to remember not to touch or remove the wildlife.
"We have even had incidents of seal pups being abandoned by mothers when too many people took selfies with them or walked their dogs off lead too close and scared the parents away.

"We want to encourage people to enjoy nature responsibly"
Fran ended up carrying one of the trapped creatures to safety after discovering it in an exposed spot along the beach.
After Storm Eunice and Franklin, starfish were seen in their hundreds on a beach in Pembrokeshire, Wales, while there has been other reports of marine life found dead.
"It is important to help if an animal needs it, but people need to do so intelligently and not interfere without thinking through the consequences first.
Wildlife guides for SeaMor Dolphin Watching Boat Trips were astonished to find two find two octopus "wandering on the beach" in New Quay.
"I know in recent storms some octopi have been found washed up dead recently, this was the first time I had ever seen any alive still."
The-28-year-old said: "Josh and I both worry quite a lot about how much wildlife and shells get disturbed and removed from the shores.
"New Quay receives a huge number of tourists each year and many do not follow the 'look but don't touch' rule," she said.
The curled octopus (Eledone cirrhosa) are not an unusual in seawater but it is surprising to see them on the shore.
Josh Pedley, one of the guides was waiking with fellow guide Fran Fitzpatrick when they saw the unusual sight.
"Responsible and informed approaches when deciding whether to touch or approach a wild animal are important".
"We ended up escorting one of the octopi back to the sea but that was under an exceptional circumstance.
A pair of octopuses were filmed 'walking' back to sea on a UK beach after a series of battering storms.
The wildlife guides said they wanted to encourage more caution from people visiting Welsh coasts.
Marine experts say sealife is often washed ashore during blustery conditions and stormy seas.
Wandering down the beach, the creatures were seen on Monday shortly before low tide.
Jellyfish such as Portuguese man o' wars were also seen washed up in Swansea.
